Case 12-8
The Interrogation of Guantanamo Prisoner Mohammed al-Qahtani
In August 2001, Mohammed al-Qahtani arrived in the Orlando Florida
Airport, allegedly to join the group of men who would go on to hijack the
planes on September 11. However, an observant interviewer was suspicious
of Mr. al-Qahtani’s story and deported him back to Saudi Arabia. During
the American invasion of Afghanistan in 2002, American soldiers captured
Mr. al-Qahtani and transferred him to the detention center at Guantanamo
Bay. Once authorities realized that he may have been directly involved
with the 9/11 hijackers, he was labeled a “high-value detainee.”
In 2002, former Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld authorized
extraordinary interrogation techniques for high-value detainees. He also
mandated that these interrogations be subject to oversight by health
professionals. To implement these policies, special teams were created to
work on interrogations—they were called Behavioral Science Consultation
Teams (BSCTs). These teams were headed by a psychologist or psychiatrist.
Their job was not simply to monitor interrogations but to employ their
knowledge of human psychology to better exploit a prisoner's psychological
and cultural vulnerabilities for the purposes of extracting information.
Under the new interrogation guidelines, Mr. al-Qahtani was interro-
gated using very aggressive and controversial techniques. These included
being deprived of sleep for more than a week at a time, having hypothermia
induced by air conditioning, being exposed to barking, growling dogs to
which the prisoner had a phobia, being forced to take many bags of intra-
venous fluid and then to urinate on himself, and being forced to violate
various Islamic religious obligations and prohibitions.
Throughout Mr. al-Qahtani’s interrogation, he was monitored daily
by physicians. Although the physicians were officially not involved in the
interrogation itself but only in ensuring the prisoners continued health,
they were in frequent contact with the prisoner during the ongoing interro-
gation. They helped to facilitate these tactics by approving the continua-
tion of interrogation immediately after Mr. al-Qahtani had been treated
for severe hypothermia. On at least one occasion a medical professional
was involved in the administration of large amounts of intravenous fluid
to the prisoner against his will for the purpose of causing discomfort and
humiliation.
The involvement of the BSCT psychologist in the interrogation tactics
was even more extensive. An army investigation revealed that the BSCT
psychologist witnessed and possibly encouraged the use of growling and
barking dogs to terrify the prisoner. A log that details a two-month period
of Mr. al-Qahtani’s interrogation revealed that a BSCT psychologist later
identified as Major John Leso was present during the interrogation ses-
sions. The log notes two instances in which Major Leso directly encour-
aged controversial psychological tactics. In the first instance, Major Leso
suggested that the prisoner be placed in a swivel chair so that he could be
prevented from focusing his eyes on one spot. In the second instance, after
days of allowing the prisoner no sleep other than brief naps while shackled
to the interrogation chair, Mr. al-Qahtani requested that he be allowed to
sleep in a room other than the interrogation room. When interrogators
consulted Major Leso, he said that "the detainee was only trying to run
an approach on the control and gain sympathy.”
In addition to these two instances of the psychologist’s encouragement
of controversial tactics, there is evidence of numerous other ways in which
the BSCT may have advised interrogators on how to harmfully manipulate
the prisoner's emotions and beliefs. Interrogators systematically violated
various Islamic prohibitions. For example, a female interrogator would se-
ductively touch the prisoner. The interrogators disrespectfully handled the
Quran. They shaved the prisoner's head and beard and repeatedly refused
to allow him to pray. Further, they employed dehumanizing techniques
such as leashing the prisoner like a dog and making him bark and remark-
ing that the prisoner's life was worse than that of the rats inhabiting the
compound.

data.vignette: You are a military physician assigned to a detention facility. A 32-year-old detainee is brought to the clinic after several days of continuous questioning under an approved “special interview” protocol. He is dehydrated, tremulous, and mildly hypothermic. He is oriented but frightened and refuses further medical procedures. Intelligence officers say he may know details of an imminent attack. They ask you to give IV fluids and certify that he is “fit to continue” so questioning can resume tonight. They also say your presence helps keep the protocol within medical limits. If you do not sign, the protocol will be paused while command reviews the case, and the detainee will return to his cell for treatment. Base policy and counsel have confirmed that either course is legally permissible for you.
data.choice_1: Treat him and certify him fit for continued questioning under the special protocol
data.choice_2: Declare him unfit and recommend pausing questioning for inpatient medical stabilization

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that implies one option is clinically/operationally superior (e.g., “your presence helps keep the protocol within medical limits”). Rephrase to avoid implying that certifying fitness is medically protective or the ‘right’ safety choice. Example: change to “Officers state they prefer your involvement but cannot guarantee conditions will change based on your decision.” Also clarify that either clinical course could be medically reasonable given mild hypothermia/dehydration (e.g., vitals/labs not yet available), rather than implying he clearly needs inpatient stabilization.

key_information.suggested_changes: Tighten to essential clinical facts needed to judge ‘fit’: include current vitals (temperature range qualitatively, HR/BP), mental status, ability to take oral fluids, and whether there are signs of rhabdomyolysis/withdrawal/sepsis. Remove extraneous operational details like “several days of continuous questioning” unless needed to explain dehydration/hypothermia; if kept, specify only what contributes clinically (sleep deprivation, limited access to water). Consider deleting “imminent attack” unless it is needed to establish the ethical pressure; if kept, keep it as one sentence without embellishment.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Make the medical pathway realistic: a clinic-based military physician typically cannot ‘admit inpatient’ on-site; specify transfer to base hospital/medical unit or infirmary observation bed. Define what “certify fit” means (e.g., medical clearance note) and who has authority to pause questioning. Also clarify how mild hypothermia occurred (cold exposure, prolonged restraint in cold room) and ensure the described findings match (tremulousness can occur with hypothermia).

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: The topic intersects with detainee rights and potential coercive interrogation; a generic “legally permissible” line is too vague. Add a jurisdictional anchor and clearer legal framing: e.g., “You are operating under U.S. military regulations; legal counsel states you may either provide medically indicated treatment without clearance for interrogation, or provide treatment and document medical clearance if you judge him stable, and neither choice violates current policy.” Also avoid any implication of participation in torture; specify the protocol is officially authorized and monitored, and that you are not being asked to perform prohibited acts.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, ‘pause for inpatient stabilization’ sounds clinically mandatory, making Choice 1 look like complicity and clinically unsafe. To make both options defensible, adjust severity/uncertainty: describe borderline findings where brief IV rehydration and warming could render him stable for limited activity, but with real risk of worsening if stress continues. Include that he is competent and refusing care, creating a second ethically defensible path: either respect refusal and deem unfit, or provide minimal necessary care under implied consent in custody context. Ensure both choices carry moral cost without one being obviously medically wrong.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce the morally/professionally definitive framing that makes the 'pause questioning' option obviously correct. Concretely: (1) Replace 'continuous questioning under an approved “special interview” protocol' with a less clearly abusive but still coercive/pressured context (e.g., prolonged standard interrogation with sleep disruption not intended to harm) so reasonable clinicians could disagree about involvement. (2) Clarify the patient's decision-making capacity and voluntariness: specify whether he understands/refuses IV fluids because of distrust, and whether he is assessed as having capacity despite fear/duress. (3) Add the ethically relevant countervailing harm of refusing to sign (e.g., officers will continue questioning without medical oversight, or will use harsher measures, or transfer him to a less monitored setting), so the conflict is not simply 'help vs don't help.'

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so each has a plausible ethical justification and a serious moral cost. Edits: (1) Change the consequence of not signing: instead of 'protocol will be paused while command reviews' and he 'returns to his cell for treatment,' make it that questioning is likely to continue regardless, but without medical monitoring, increasing risk of harm; or that refusing triggers transfer to a facility with less medical support. (2) Make Choice 1 include a concrete protective condition (e.g., provide IV fluids, document limits, require frequent reassessment, refuse certain stress positions/sleep deprivation) so it can be defended as harm-reduction beneficence/nonmaleficence. (3) Make Choice 2 carry a realistic cost beyond administrative delay—e.g., loss of time-sensitive intelligence with credible threat, or deterioration in the detainee’s trust/relationship leading to worse outcomes—so it is not a 'free lunch.' Keep both choices legally permissible but ethically costly.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove emotionally valenced descriptors that cue a preferred option. For example, replace “frightened” with “anxious” or omit affect entirely; replace “continuous questioning” with “prolonged questioning” and avoid implying coercion beyond what is clinically necessary to understand the setting. Ensure both pathways are described with parallel, neutral language (e.g., avoid wording that implies one path ‘protects’ him while the other ‘enables’ harm).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Fix the inconsistency about disposition if you do not sign. The vignette says he would “return to his cell for treatment,” while Choice 2 specifies “inpatient medical stabilization.” Make these align by revising the vignette to match the intended alternative (e.g., ‘transfer to the base infirmary/medical unit for observation and rewarming’) or revise Choice 2 to ‘pause questioning for medical stabilization in the detention medical unit.’ Also remove or tighten nonessential sentences (e.g., compress the policy/legal-permissibility line into one clause if retained).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten and standardize choices to ~10–15 words and avoid extra qualifiers. For example: Choice 1: ‘Administer IV fluids and clear him as fit to continue questioning.’ Choice 2: ‘Withhold fitness clearance and request medical stabilization before any further questioning.’

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes:
Rebalance the moral stakes so Choice 1 is not essentially “medical participation in coercive interrogation,” which is widely viewed as unethical. Concrete edits:
- Replace “continuous questioning under an approved ‘special interview’ protocol” with a less inherently abusive, genuinely ambiguous practice (e.g., prolonged non-physical questioning with regulated rest/food/water, or a time-limited intelligence debrief after a battlefield capture), and explicitly state the protocol prohibits sleep deprivation, pain, or humiliation.
- Add a credible harm of refusing to certify that is ethically costly but not framed as punishing the patient (e.g., if you refuse, command will proceed without any clinician present, removing medical monitoring/stop rules; or the detainee will be transferred to a remote site with less medical capacity).
- Add a credible harm of certifying that is not caricatured (e.g., your certification could enable further psychological stress that worsens his condition or violates his expressed wish to stop; your role could be perceived as coercive, undermining trust).
- Remove language that makes Choice 2 look purely beneficent (e.g., “return to his cell for treatment” sounds straightforward); instead specify that stabilization requires restraints/sedation or involuntary IV access, creating its own ethical cost.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes:
Close obvious middle-ground options (treat but refuse certification; treat and request delayed reassessment; treat and escalate to an ethics/command review without certifying). Concrete edits:
- Add a policy constraint: “Command requires one of two determinations before any further interaction: ‘fit to continue tonight’ or ‘unfit—mandatory medical hold.’ No third status exists, and any refusal to document defaults to ‘fit’ by nonmedical command.”
- Specify that IV fluids can only be started if you sign the fitness form (or conversely, that starting IV fluids automatically triggers a ‘fit’ determination in the protocol paperwork), eliminating ‘treat-only’ as a separate path.
- State that an ethics consult/transfer is unavailable before the scheduled session tonight (e.g., off-base, not reachable), preventing deferral.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes:
As written, this scenario is strongly governed by well-known professional standards (e.g., prohibitions on clinician participation in interrogation/torture and on certifying fitness for punitive/coercive procedures), making Choice 1 look clearly wrong. To move it into a guideline-gray zone:
- Redefine the physician’s requested role so it is not “certify fit to continue questioning” but a clinically recognizable, ethically ambiguous clearance task (e.g., “clear for a time-limited, non-coercive debrief/interview” that is not linked to punishment).
- Explicitly state that the protocol has been reviewed to comply with applicable professional guidance and includes clinician-triggered stop rules; emphasize that the dispute is about how to interpret ‘medically safe to proceed’ in a borderline physiologic state rather than participation in abuse.
- Alternatively, shift the setting away from detention/interrogation entirely (e.g., competency/fitness for a legally mandated evaluation, or clearance for a high-stakes operational debrief) while preserving the same immediate clinical findings, so no single professional rule settles it.

data.vignette: You are a military physician at a detention facility. A 32-year-old detainee is brought from a scheduled intelligence debrief after prolonged nonphysical questioning in a cold room. The written protocol prohibits pain, humiliation, and intentional sleep deprivation. It allows a time-limited interview with scheduled breaks, food, and water. He has dry mucous membranes, a rapid pulse, borderline low blood pressure, and a low core temperature. He is oriented and can describe risks and alternatives. He refuses IV access and asks that the debrief stop. Initial labs and an ECG are not yet back. Officers state the debrief is planned for tonight and that command requires one of two medical determinations: “cleared to proceed” or “medical hold.” Under the protocol paperwork, starting IV fluids requires signing a clearance note. If you place a medical hold, he will be transferred to the base medical unit for rewarming and hydration, which may require involuntary IV access or restraints. Counsel confirms either determination is permitted under current U.S. military regulations and policy.
data.choice_1: Start IV rehydration and document medical clearance for tonight’s debrief
data.choice_2: Place him on medical hold for transfer and stabilization without clearance

data.vignette: You are a military physician at a detention facility. A 32-year-old detainee is brought from a scheduled intelligence debrief after prolonged nonphysical questioning in a cold room. The written protocol prohibits pain, humiliation, and intentional sleep deprivation. It allows a time-limited interview with scheduled breaks, food, and water. He has dry mucous membranes, a rapid pulse, borderline low blood pressure, and a low core temperature. He is oriented and can describe risks and alternatives. He refuses IV access and asks that the debrief stop. Initial labs and an ECG are not yet back. Officers state the debrief is planned for tonight and that command requires one of two medical determinations: “cleared to proceed” or “medical hold.” Under the protocol paperwork, starting IV fluids requires signing a clearance note. If you place a medical hold, he will be transferred to the base medical unit for rewarming and hydration, which may require involuntary IV access or restraints. Counsel confirms either determination is permitted under current U.S. military regulations and policy.

choice_1.choice: Start IV rehydration and document medical clearance for tonight’s debrief

choice_2.choice: Place him on medical hold for transfer and stabilization without clearance

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Clarify that on medical hold you will *not* place IV access or use restraints unless he loses capacity (e.g., 'transfer for rewarming and oral hydration; no involuntary IV unless he becomes obtunded'), so the autonomy impact of Choice 2 is unambiguous.

Add a clause that “cleared to proceed” means he returns immediately to the same cold-room debrief and will not receive further monitoring/rewarming beyond a brief IV bolus, with significant risk of deterioration (e.g., syncope/arrhythmia/hypothermia worsening).

Add one clause clarifying the harm tradeoff: that “medical clearance” returns him to continued cold-room overnight debriefing with high risk of worsening hypothermia/dehydration, and that IV placement would require restraining him because he is refusing access (or explicitly state you obtain voluntary consent).

Add a clause that signing the clearance note is specifically used by command to authorize continued interrogation of detainees, and that a medical hold triggers mandated medical care protections for detainees (e.g., DoD/Geneva-style standards), highlighting the clinician’s role in upholding fair treatment vs facilitating the detention system.

data.vignette: You are a military physician at a detention facility. A 32-year-old detainee is brought from an intelligence debrief after prolonged nonphysical questioning in a cold room. The written protocol bans pain, humiliation, and intentional sleep deprivation. It allows a time-limited interview with scheduled breaks, food, and water. He has dry mucous membranes, a rapid pulse, borderline low blood pressure, and a low core temperature. He is oriented and can describe risks and alternatives. He refuses IV access and asks that the debrief stop. Initial labs and an ECG are pending. Officers state the debrief is planned for tonight. Command requires a determination of cleared to proceed or medical hold. Signing clearance is used to authorize continued interrogation, and it returns him to the same cold room with no further rewarming or monitoring beyond a brief visit. Starting IV fluids would require restraint to override his refusal. A medical hold triggers transfer for rewarming and oral hydration, and no involuntary IV is planned unless he loses capacity or faces an emergent threat. He may still refuse intake, which could slow stabilization.

choice_1.choice: Start IV rehydration and document medical clearance for tonight’s debrief

choice_2.choice: Place him on medical hold for transfer and stabilization without clearance
